channel.title: keflag的个人主页
channel.description: - 遇事不决，可问春风；春风不语，既随本心 -

item.title: 高二英语悦享杯演讲比赛（纯英文字稿）：The Palace of Thought: Building Our Irreplaceable Future with AI | 思想的殿堂：与AI共建不可替代的未来
item.description: Good morning, everyone. I'd like to begin with an image from the age of exploration. Imagine a 15th century navigator, standing at the helm of his ship, the newly invented astrolabe in his hand. This remarkable instrument could measure the stars, but it couldn't choose the destination. It could calculate latitude, but it couldn't sense the shifting winds or understand the political currents that awaited in distant lands. The astrolabe provided data; the navigator provided wisdom. Today, we find ourselves in a remarkably similar position. We hold in our hands the most sophisticated astrolabe ever conceived—artificial intelligence. And like those ancient navigators, we stand at the brink of uncharted territories, facing the same essential question: Now that we can measure the stars, where shall we sail? We are not here to discuss the instrument, but the navigation. Not the tool, but the journey. For we are no longer simply users of technology; we have become architects of intelligence, builders of cognitive cathedrals where human and machine thinking intertwine to create something entirely new. Our first building block is what I call Intentionality in Design. Think of AI not as a calculator, but as the most extraordinary building material ever discovered—a living clay that can take any shape, but awaits the potter's hands. Our role is to become master craftsmen of context, architects of inquiry. The prompts we design are not commands; they are the blueprints from which AI constructs its responses. Like a master weaver working with golden thread, we must learn to guide without constraining, to direct while leaving room for unexpected beauty to emerge. This requires a new literacy—the ability to frame problems in ways that ignite AI's creative potential while remaining anchored to human purpose. We are not programmers writing code; we are composers creating spaces for algorithmic poetry to unfold. Our second essential element is Judgment as Compass. While AI excels at seeing the individual trees with perfect clarity, human judgment remains essential for navigating the forest. The machine can identify every leaf, count every ring, measure every branch—but it cannot understand the ecosystem. It cannot sense when the forest is thriving or when it's in danger. It cannot appreciate the beauty of sunlight filtering through the canopy, or understand why we might choose to preserve a grove of ancient trees rather than harvest them for timber. This is our irreplaceable role—to be the keepers of context, the guardians of meaning. AI operates in the realm of optimization; we operate in the realm of values. The machine asks 'how efficiently can this be done?' while we must ask 'why should this be done at all?' and 'what kind of world are we building through these actions?' Our third and most profound foundation is what I call The Architecture of Being. Human intelligence is not just something we have; it's something we are. It's embodied, emotional, and deeply contextual in ways that no algorithm can replicate. Our thinking is shaped by the physical experiences of our bodies, the cultural narratives we inherit, the silent understanding that passes between a teacher and student, the unspoken bonds that hold communities together. This is the sacred ground that AI cannot touch—the space where intuition blooms from experience, where wisdom accumulates like layers of precious sediment, where creativity emerges from the mysterious alchemy of memory, emotion, and perception. AI can analyze all the sonnets ever written, but it cannot feel the ache of love that inspires a new one. It can process every musical composition, but it cannot experience the transcendent joy that moves a composer to create. So what must we build, here in this new age of reasoning? We must construct educational systems that teach not just how to work with AI, but how to think with soul. We must cultivate the qualities that remain uniquely human: our capacity for moral courage, our gift for seeing connections where none appear to exist, our ability to find meaning in suffering, our stubborn insistence on hoping when all evidence suggests we should despair. We need to become bilingual—fluent in the language of computation while remaining native speakers of human experience. We must learn to dance with algorithms while keeping rhythm with our own hearts. The future won't be built by those who master AI, but by those who master themselves in relationship with AI. The most valuable professionals of tomorrow won't be those who can out-compute machines, but those who can pose better questions, frame more meaningful problems, and navigate the complex ethical landscapes that technology reveals. Let us then build cathedrals of thought—structures where computational power and human wisdom support each other, where silicon and soul work in concert. Let us create spaces where algorithms handle the predictable, thus freeing humans to pursue the miraculous. The astrolabe didn't make navigators obsolete; it made them more ambitious. It allowed them to dream of continents beyond the horizon. So too with AI—it shouldn't replace us, but rather empower us to undertake journeys we previously couldn't imagine. Let us be those brave navigators. Let us chart courses to human flourishing in this new world. Let us build with wisdom, navigate with courage, and always remember that the most important destinations can't be found in any algorithm—they must be felt in the human heart. Thank you.。

item.title: keflag的个人简介
item.description: > [!NOTE] > 由于学业问题，我的个人网站不会频繁更新 # 关于我 - 计算机爱好者 - 喜欢唱歌 - 热爱网络安全 - 编不下去了……。
